user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SetLocalTime_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SetLocalTime_Impl(const OS_time_t *time_struct)
{
    int             Status;
    int32           ReturnCode;
    struct timespec TimeSp;

    TimeSp.tv_sec  = OS_TimeGetTotalSeconds(*time_struct);
    TimeSp.tv_nsec = OS_TimeGetNanosecondsPart(*time_struct);

    Status = clock_settime(OSAL_GETTIME_SOURCE_CLOCK, &TimeSp);

    if (Status == 0)
    {
        ReturnCode = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        ReturnCode = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return ReturnCode;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SetLocalTime_Impl:
typedef struct
{
    int64 ticks; /**< Ticks elapsed since reference point */
} OS_time_t
...
static inline int64 OS_TimeGetTotalSeconds(OS_time_t tm)
{
    return (tm.ticks / OS_TIME_TICKS_PER_SECOND);
}
...
static inline uint32 OS_TimeGetNanosecondsPart(OS_time_t tm)
{
    return (uint32)OS_TimeGetFractionalPart(tm) * OS_TIME_TICK_RESOLUTION_NS;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragments in the provided function modify the function parameter. The parameter is declared as const OS_time_t *time_struct, so the object pointed-to is read-only in this function; only read accesses occur (the expressions *time_struct passed to OS_TimeGetTotalSeconds and OS_TimeGetNanosecondsPart). There is no assignment to or arithmetic on the parameter variable time_struct itself (no reassignments like time_struct = ..., no increment/decrement, no pointer arithmetic). The helper functions shown take OS_time_t by value, so they do not modify any pointer parameter here. The only object modified is the local TimeSp variable (and it is passed by address to clock_settime), which is not a function parameter. Therefore there are no fragments that need investigation for potential violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in the provided code.
